TAXONOMIC CLASS.content: TAXONOMIC CLASS: Fine-loamy, mixed, active, acid, mesic Typic Hydraquents

TYPICAL PEDON.content:
TYPICAL PEDON:  Featherstone silt loam on 0 to 1 percent slopes in a marshy wooded area.
0i--2 to 0 inches; mosses and partially decomposed organic matter.
A--0 to 14 inches; very dark grayish brown (10YR 3/2) mucky silt loam; structureless; very friable, slightly sticky, slightly plastic; many fine medium and coarse roots; many decomposing roots and organic debris; 15 percent organic carbon; strongly acid; clear smooth boundary (3 to 16 inches thick).
Cg--14 to 38 inches; dark grayish brown (10YR 4/2) loam; many medium and coarse prominent very dark gray (10YR 3/1) mottles; structureless; friable, slightly sticky, slightly plastic; common fine roots; 1 percent fine quartz gravel; strongly acid; abrupt smooth boundary.
C--38 to 72 inches; dark yellowish brown (10YR 4/4) loam; many medium and fine distinct dark gray (10YR 4/1) mottles; structureless; friable; slightly sticky, slightly plastic; few fine roots; 1 percent; fine quartz gravel; strongly acid.

TYPE LOCATION.content: TYPE LOCATION: Type Location:  Prince William County, Virginia; 1/2 mile south of Va. Route 636 and 300 yards east of R.F.& P. Railroad, near Farm Creek.

RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS.content:
RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS:  Rock fragments of quartz gravel range from 0 to 5 percent in the A horizon and 1 to 10 percent in the C horizon.  Depth to bedrock is more than 5 feet.  Reaction is strongly acid or very strongly acid.
The A horizon has hue of 10YR, value of 3 or 4, and chroma of 0 through 3.  Organic matter content ranges from 10 to 30 percent.  Texture is mucky loam or mucky silt loam with more than 8 percent clay and N value of more than 0.7.
The C horizon has hue of 7.5YR or 10YR, value of 3 or 4, and chroma of 1 through 4.  It is loam or silt loam.

COMPETING SERIES.content: COMPETING SERIES:  There are no competing series in this family.  Closely related series are Bibb, Bohicket and Levy soils.  Bibb soils are coarse-loamy.  Bohicket soils are sulfaquents and Levy soils have temperature less than 59 degrees F.

GEOGRAPHIC SETTING.content: GEOGRAPHIC SETTING:  Featherstone soils are on level to nearly level floodplains in the Coastal Plain.  They do not flood daily but are subject to high seasonal tides and storm tides.  The water table is commonly at the surface and most areas are subject to ponding.  These soils are commonly at sea level or up to two feet above sea level.  Mean annual precipitation ranges from about 38 to 44 inches.  Mean annual temperature ranges from about 57 to 60 degrees F.

GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS.content: GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS:  In addition to the competing series, the Rappahannock soils are associated soils.  The Rappahannock soils are Terric Sulfihemists.

DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY.content: DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY:  Very poorly drained; very slow to ponded runoff; moderate permeability.  The water table is near the surface to ponded from 6 to 8 months each year.

USE AND VEGETATION.content: USE AND VEGETATION:  Dominantly woody species with few larger trees of red maple and sweetgum.  Cattails, skunk cabbage and reeds make up much of the vegetation.  Many areas are partially covered with debris.  Distribution and Extent:  Along the streams flowing into the Chesapeake Bay, Maryland and Virginia.  The series is of small extent.

ORIGIN.section: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE
ORIGIN.content: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE: Raleigh, North Carolina

REMARKS.content: SERIES ESTABLISHED:  Prince William County, Virginia, 1985.
